p: The crude, semi-purified and purified aqueous extracts of the roots of Fagara zanthoxyloides, known as Senegal prickly-ash, displayed highly promising antiplasmodial activity with IC 50 values of 4.90, 1.00, and 0.13 μg/mL, respectively, using the [ 3H]-hypoxanthine incorporation assay. Further separation yielded a very potent antiplasmodial benzophenanthridine alkaloid, fagaronine ( 7) with an IC 50 of 0.018 μg/mL against P. falciparum strain 3D7 (Kassim et al., 2005). A short and efficient synthesis for this compound was developed by Rivaud et al. ( 2012), who also confirmed the compound's activity against chloroquine-sensitive and -resistant P. falciparum isolates superior to chloroquine with half maximal effective concentration (EC 50) of ~10 nM in vitro and comparable to chloroquine against P. vinckei in vivo [median effective dose (ED 50) of 6 mg/Kg/day for 4 days]. Moreover, the compound, displayed no toxicity against Vero cells in vitro (Rivaud et al., 2012) or by single injection in the mouse at up to 50 mg/Kg (Nakanishi et al., 1999). The methanol extract of F. zanthoxyloides also displayed >90% inhibition of Plasmodium berghei in vivo, with an estimated EC 50 of 235 mg/Kg b.w. for the extract while the lethal dose 50 (LD 50) was >5,000 mg/Kg b.w. in mice (Enechi et al., 2019), providing independent confirmation of the antimalarial potential of this plant.
